review.title: HPSLPred: An Ensemble Multi-label Classifier for Human Protein Subcellular Location Prediction with Imbalanced Source
review.abstract: Predicting the subcellular localization of proteins is an important and challenging problem. Traditional experimental approaches are often expensive and time-consuming. Consequently, a growing number of research efforts employ a series of machine learning approaches to predict the subcellular location of proteins. There are two main challenges among the state-of-the-art prediction methods. First, most of the existing techniques are designed to deal with multi-class rather than multi-label classification, which ignores connections between multiple labels. In reality, multiple locations of particular proteins implies that there are vital and unique biological significances that deserve special focus and cannot be ignored. Second, techniques for handling imbalanced data in multi-label classification problems are necessary, but never employed. For solving these two issues, we have developed an ensemble multi-label classifier called HPSLPred, which can be applied for multi-label classification with an imbalanced protein source. For convenience, a user-friendly webserver has been established at

metadata.title: HPSLPred: An Ensemble Multi-label Classifier for Human Protein Subcellular Location Prediction with Imbalanced Source

sections.text: Traditional biological experiments are expensive and time-consuming, so more and more research interests are tending toward a series of machine learning approaches to predicting the subcellular protein layer. There are two main problems among existing state-of-the-art methods. Firstly, most existing techniques are designed to deal with multi-class classification, but not multi-brand classification, which ignores the link between the different labels. In reality, multi-label proteins imply that there are vital and unique biological meanings that deserve special attention and cannot be ignored. Secondly, the techniques for handling unbalanced data in multi-label classification are important, but less so. To solve both problems, we have developed a multi-brand classifier called HPSLPred, which can be used for multi-label classification with an unbalanced protein source. For the convenience of users, a user-friendly web server for HPPPred multiple-cell classification, Multiple Classification, has been set up at: http: / ab.Pab.n.

sections.heading: 2.3 Features for subcellular localization
sections.text: In this section, all human protein sequences are extracted into datasets and have vectors based on machine learning. In order to take the properties of protein sequences more fully into account, our approach takes into account two state-of-the-art feature models: 188-dimension63 and Pse-in-One64,65,188-dimensional feature model contains eight types of physical chemical properties or hydrophobicity, normalized van der Waals volumes, polarity, polarity, charge, surface tension, secondary structure and solvent accessibility. For the components of the 188 dimension, the first 20 dimensions represent the proportions of the 20 types of amino acids, while the remaining dimensions consist of eight types of more comprehensive physical properties containing twenty-one attributes. Therefore, each protein sequence produces 188 (20 + (21) x 8) numerical values.

sections.heading: 2.4 HPSLPred: a novel and ensemble multi-label classifier
sections.text: HPSLPred is an ensemble multi-line with unbalanced source code, and we are designing a more comprehensive model that we need to take care of to achieve the best possible performance. It is about the way in which we use all seven methods of extraction in pse-in-one and 188-dimensional methods, which we then express in different views. Hybrid features model can be seen in some works, and they can achieve more accurate prediction, but it is undeniable that it contains some redundant expressions, so we are applying an uncomplicated reduction method called the Max Relevance Distance Method (MRMD66) for the dimensions.

sections.heading: 2.5 Performance metrics
sections.text: There are several metrics for the problem of multi-label classification, e.g. Hamming loss, Coverage, OneError, IsError, Ranking loss and Average precision (AP). The metric that is most relevant for the performance of the multi-label classification system is the AP value, which is between 0 and 1. AP metric can be formulated as follows: () = 1 (,) (,) (,) (,) (,)

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text: Based on a series of detailed descriptions in the sections above, we will evaluate whether our approach is better or not. First, our approach using the 188D feature model will test the performance of the Mulan, WEKA and HPSLPred-based Scikit Learning. The precision of each label or subcellular position will be clearly demonstrated. Similarly, we will also demonstrate the performance of the PseAAC-26D feature model and the 350D hybrid feature model, which includes an additional presentation on the optimal two-layer dimensional search. In addition, we have modestly compared our approach to some state-of-the-art methods to increase persuasive power. Except for such extensive experiments, we offer researchers the entire source code in public and an easy-to-use web server.

sections.text: In this subsection we will show all the experiments on PseAAC-26D that have achieved very good results in many previous work. PseAAC-26D is one of the protein sequences that has extraction methods based on the pseudo-amino acid composition. sections.heading: 3.4 Comparison with state-of-the-art methods

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text: In this section, a series of experiments shown above will be compared with each other, and we will conclude by analyzing the value and defect of each method. From three experiments (a), (b) and (c) based on the 188D characteristic model, we will summarize three important conclusions: (1). The HPSLPred classifier integrates twelve types of basic classifiers and adds grid parameters, thereby achieving the highest AP value. (2) Mulan-based multi-label classifiers are better than classic WEKA-based single-label classifiers, proving that Mulan is an excellent work. (3). The precision of each label corresponds to its AP value, which excludes the consistency of the results. From three experiments (d), (e) and (f) based PseAAC-26D classifiers, we draw a new conclusion: There is no obvious relationship between the results of PAC and the new Ase8 results, so that an expression of them exists.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, we create hybrid 350D feature-based 188D feature and all methods of Pse-in-One, transform the original multi-label unbalanced source into multiple single-label unbalanced data set-based BM method, transform single-label unbalanced data sets into single-label unbalanced data set-based SVM decision limit, integrate twelve basic classifiers based on scikit learning and match optimal parameters by grid search, search for the optimum dimension through MRMD and two round dimension reduction and finally achieve the highest AP value. In addition, we use multi-thread technology to accelerate multiple processes in dimensionality reduction. This is our novel and ensemble classifier HPSLPred with unbalanced source. For the convenience of the user, we have developed a user-friendly web server for PHL.http / in order to provide a fully functional web server for PHLred research.

metadata.abstractText: Protein subcellular localization prediction is an important and challenging problem. The traditional biology experiments are expensive and time-consuming, so more and more research interests tend to a series of machine learning approaches for predicting protein subcellular location. There are two main difficult problems among the existing state-of-the-art methods. First, most of the existing techniques are designed to deal with the multi-class but not the multi-label classification, which ignores the connection between the multiple labels. In reality, multiple location proteins implicate that there are vital and unique biological significances worthy of special focus, which cannot be ignored. Second, the techniques for handling imbalanced data in multi-label classification problem is significant but less. For solving the two issues, we have developed an ensemble multi-label classifier called HPSLPred which can be applied for the multi-label classification with imbalanced protein source. For the conveniences of users, a user-friendly webserver for HPSLPred was established at http://server.malab.cn/HPSLPred.
